title: City braced for Thomas Cook results after Tunisia and Greece crises
text:
Save 
City analysts have estimated that the Greek and Tunisian crises could cost Thomas Cook around £20 million, according to weekend reports. 
Investors were said to be braced for the travel giant to outline the hit it has taken from the deadly terrorist attack in Tunisia and economic crisis in Greece when it posts its results this week, the Sunday Telegraph reported. 
The tour operator is due to report its third-quarter numbers on Thursday, covering the three months to the end of June and is expected to update shareholders about how Greece and the fears about Tunisia have impacted the business. 
Thomas Cook cancelled all bookings to Tunisia until the end of October after the FCO altered its advice to warn against all but essential travel to the country following the devastating terror attack which killed 30 Britons. 
The company is also thought to have been impacted by the ongoing financial situation in Greece, as tourists were urged to carry plenty of cash with them, prompting fears about theft which some analysts said could have deterred holidaymakers. 
Credit Suisse estimates that Greece typically accounts for around 15% of passenger volumes during the summer season. 
The crises in Tunisia and Greece come at an already difficult time for Thomas Cook, after it faced calls for a boycott in May after an inquest ruled that it had breached its duty of care when two children died of carbon monoxide poisoning while on a Thomas Cook holiday in 2006. Two months ago however, chief executive Peter Fankhauser said although it was “early stages”, bookings had not suffered from a backlash among British customers.
